aws::graph::propositions: # Embraer EMB-505 Aircraft Incident in Palm Springs with Rudder Gust Lock Failure
The incident occurred in Palm Springs, California.
The incident occurred on November 23, 2014, at 11:04 Local time.
The aircraft involved was an Embraer EMB-505.
The defining event was System/Component malfunction/failure (non-power).
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The incident number was WPR15IA046.
The aircraft registration was C-GJOL.
The aircraft sustained minor damage.
There were 5 people on board with no injuries.
An airline transport pilot was operating the aircraft.
The flight was a personal cross-country flight.
The pilot reported that preflight preparations were normal.
The pilot removed the rudder gust lock pin during preflight.
The taxi out for takeoff was normal.
The pilot detected an abnormal feel to the rudders during taxi.
All turns to the runway were right turns.
The pilot easily executed the right turns during taxi.
Following rotation on takeoff, the pilot noticed a significant right yaw and roll.
The pilot initially countered the right yaw and roll with left aileron.
As the airplane continued to climb, the flight was uncoordinated.
The pilot had to continuously apply left rudder to counter the right yaw.
The pilot attempted to apply left yaw trim.
Neither the left rudder nor left yaw trim resolved the issue.
The pilot advised air traffic control that he needed to return to the departure airport.
Air traffic control cleared the pilot for a visual approach.
The pilot landed the airplane.
The left wing tip sustained minor damage.
The damage occurred as the pilot unsuccessfully tried to correct a drift to the right after landing.
The pilot attempted to correct the drift using right rudder and aileron.
Initial examination revealed the rudder gust lock had failed in the locked position.
Further examination determined the gust lock actuator had likely begun to retract as commanded.
The solenoid located within the gust lock actuator failed.
The solenoid failure resulted in the pin no longer being held in the retracted position.
Once the pin released from its retracted position, it engaged the ball nut.
The engagement of the ball nut stopped the rotation of the actuator shaft.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Palm Springs, California

## Date & Time: 
November 23, 2014, 11:04 Local

## Aircraft:
Embraer EMB-505

## Defining Event:
Sys/Comp malf/fail (non-power)

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Incident Number:
WPR15IA046

## Registration:
C-GJOL

## Aircraft Damage:
Minor

## Injuries:
5 None

## Analysis

The airline transport pilot was preparing to take off for a personal cross-country flight. He reported that the preflight preparations were normal, including the removal of the rudder gust lock pin. He stated that the taxi out for takeoff was normal but that he "detected an abnormal 'feel' to the rudders." He added that all of the turns to the runway were right turns and that he "easily executed" the turns. Following rotation on takeoff, the pilot noticed a significant right yaw and roll, which he initially countered with left aileron. As the airplane continued to climb, the airplane's flight was uncoordinated, and the pilot had to continuously apply left rudder to counter the right yaw; he also attempted to apply left yaw trim, but neither action resolved the issue. At this time, the pilot advised air traffic control (ATC) that he needed to return to the departure airport, and ATC cleared the pilot for a visual approach. The pilot landed the airplane; only minor damage to the left wing tip was incurred as the pilot tried to unsuccessfully correct (with the right rudder and aileron) a drift to the right after landing.

The initial examination of the airplane revealed that the rudder gust lock had failed in the locked position. Upon further examination, it was determined that the gust lock actuator had likely begun to retract as commanded by the pilot when he removed the rudder gust lock pin during the preflight/startup checks. However, the solenoid located within the gust lock actuator failed, which resulted in the pin no longer being held in the retracted position. Once the pin released from its retracted position, it engaged the ball nut, which then stopped the rotation of the actuator shaft.
